results.title: Air crew
results.creator_credit: Geoffrey Thompson and Australia. Royal Air Force. Films Advisory Bureau
results.brief_description: The training of pilots and navigators for careers in the Royal Australian Air Force is described in detail. Young men with strong mathematical aptitudes excel in these fields, especially navigation. Training is carried out in a number of RAAF schools in different parts of the Commonwealth. The film closes with an account of life on the Australian base at Butterworth in Malaya.

results.title: Agronomy
results.creator_credit: Jean Palardy, Raymond Garceau and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Describes the introduction of co-operative dairy farming in the eastern townships of Quebec to increase agricultural output and improve marketing methods. Recalls some of the difficulties encountered in the early days of the Agricultural Co-operative of Granby and cites the success of the Granby Co-operative as an example of what can be achieved when agricultural expert and farmer work in close co-operation.

results.title: Agriculture today in Japan
results.creator_credit: Iwanami Productions for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Japan
results.brief_description: Shows the modern methods widely used in Japanese agriculture due to the influence of the country’s increasing industrialisation. Illustrates scientific farming methods, co-operative production and marketing.

results.title: Agriculture, industry and power
results.creator_credit: United States Information Agency and Warner-Pathe News
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Atoms for Peace”.
Describes research into the practical and beneficial uses of atomic energy and radioactive materials in agricultural and industrial production. Highlights Gama rays being used to develop better crop species, radioactive cobalt assisting fertiliser research, atomic energy detecting flaws in castings, checking wear on piston rings and, food preservation, synthetic fuel and electric power applications.

results.title: An Agricultural Officer in Papua and New Guinea
results.creator_credit: William Shepherd, Maslyn Williams, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: Presents the work being done in Papua and New Guinea by the Department of Agriculture to produce better stock and crops, and the opportunities for young men in this field. Various special training and research centres are shown, including the veterinary laboratory, rubber experimental station, cattle breeding station, and extension centres where people are trained as Agricultural Field Assistants.

results.creator_credit_for_label: William Shepherd, Maslyn Williams, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Australian National Film Board

results.title: The Ageing of the lakes
results.creator_credit: John Walker and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Explains the process of the natural ageing and eventual death of lakes, called eutrophication. Also links man’s environmental interference with the changes in the lakes and investigates current efforts to retard eutrophication and preserve and restore lakes in America. Discusses pollution and methods for its control.

results.title: Prosthetic Head
results.brief_description: Prosthetic Head, is a computer-generated head that has real-time lip synching, speech synthesis, and facial expressions. Through a vision or sensor system, the Prosthetic Head will be able to acknowledge the presence and position of any physical body that approaches it and speak to the person who interrogates it.

results.title: Embrace
results.creator_credit: Kerreen Ely-Harper, Lindy Macauley, Arts Education, NMIT and Northern Metropolitan Institute of TAFE
results.brief_description:
Embrace, launched in May 2000 by the Minister for Community Services, is the second dance film produced by NMIT (Northern Melbourne Institute of TAFE) featuring dancers with disabilities. Having experience of Loup - a film commemorating the year of the ocean, the artists (in Embrace) further explored the notion of creative expression and different spaces for dancers with disabilities.
Embrace was filmed in the green surroundings of Merri Creek and in the urban landscape of concrete and graffiti at the St Georges Rd bypass. The movements and actions were a direct result of interactions between the dancers and the landscape. The film, filled with beauty, humour and warmth, explores the themes of Hamlet’s soliloquy to be or not to be, namely the themes of betrayal, alienation, desire to escape and the place of dreams in our waking lives.
Embrace was funded by the Australian Council for the Arts, the City of Boroondara, the Department of Human Services and NMIT. The dancers had the opportunity during the production to work with professional artists from diverse backgrounds and expertise.
Embrace was screened at numerous national and international film festivals including the Dance on Camera festival in New York, January 2001. The principal artist, Randal Aitkin, gave a live performance at the screening of Embrace in New York. The significance of that event lies in the fact that the NMIT dance student qualified to perform among the elite of world dancers while overcoming difficulties arising from intellectual disability. Excerpts from Embrace appeared in the Arte programs on the National French and German Television Networks between December 2001 and February 2002.

results.title: Loup
results.creator_credit: Kerreen Ely-Harper and Northern Metropolitan Institute of TAFE
results.brief_description:
Loup showcases the talents of the Arts Education dance group students (with disabilities) from NMIT (Northern Melbourne Institute of TAFE). Loup, full of zest and the notion: to dance; to flee; to leap; to burst, lit up the dancers’ desire to devise creative expression in open spaces. In Loup, commemorating the year of the life of the ocean, the dancers, through improvised movements, developed their vision towards a common destination - the sea. Its openness and vastness, power and force depict the energy of freedom that eliminates all barriers. Barriers that may arise from disabilities are suddenly irrelevant.
Loup was filmed at the Jawbone site in the Wetlands in Williamstown. This is a protected conservation area and is used as a metaphor to represent the dancers’ expectation of a safe and open space in which to be, and express freely.
After a decade of regular dance workshops and performances, the artists naturally progressed into a new stage ‘ exploration of dance with media. Creative camera work captured the integrity of their movements. This art form expanded the dimensions of the discipline much practiced by the dancers. At the same time it enabled the documentation of the works thus creating new resources in the field.
Loup, since its production in 1998, has been screened at national and international festivals and community events.
